RMDIR(1) General Commands Manual RMDIR(1)

NAME

rmdir — remove empty directories

SYNOPSIS

rmdir [-pv] [--help] [--version] [--ignore-fail-on-non-empty] [--parents] [--verbose] directory ...

DESCRIPTION

The rmdir utility removes the directory entry specified by each directory argument, provided it is empty.

Arguments are processed in the order given. In order to remove both a parent directory and a subdirectory of that parent, the subdirectory must be specified first so the parent directory is empty when rmdir tries to remove it.

The options are as follows:

-h, --help
Display help information and exit.
-V, --version
Display version information and exit.
-p, --parents
Remove directory and its ancestors. For example, ‘rmdir -p a/b/c’ is similar to ‘rmdir a/b/c a/b a’. The specified directories are removed in order, from leaf to root. If any removal fails, processing stops at that point.
-v, --verbose
Be verbose, showing directories as they are processed.
--ignore-fail-on-non-empty
Each failure to remove a directory because it is non-empty is ignored. Without this option, rmdir will print an error message and continue processing remaining directories.

EXIT STATUS

The rmdir utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs. The rmdir utility exits with one of the following values:

0
Each directory entry specified by a directory operand was removed successfully.
>0
An error occurred.

EXAMPLES

Remove the directory foobar, if it is empty:

$ rmdir foobar

Remove all directories up to and including cow, stopping at the first non-empty directory (if any):

$ rmdir -p cow/horse/monkey

Remove multiple empty directories with verbose output:

$ rmdir -v dir1 dir2 dir3
rmdir: removing directory, 'dir1'
rmdir: removing directory, 'dir2'
rmdir: removing directory, 'dir3'

Clean up empty directory tree, ignoring non-empty directories:

$ rmdir --ignore-fail-on-non-empty -p project/build/temp

DIAGNOSTICS

The rmdir utility will print an error message if:

  • A specified directory does not exist.
  • A specified directory is not empty (unless --ignore-fail-on-non-empty is used).
  • The user does not have permission to remove a directory.
  • A specified path is not a directory.

SEE ALSO

mkdir(1), rm(1)

STANDARDS

The rmdir utility is expected to be IEEE Std 1003.2 (“POSIX.2”) compatible.

AUTHORS

vibeutils implementation by Travis Cole
